lend.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to let someone borrow money or something that belongs to you for a short time
lend.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I lent my CD player to Dave and I haven’t got it back yet.
The hospital agreed to lend us a wheelchair.
Can you lend me £10 until tomorrow?
lend.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: if a bank or financial institution lends money, it lets someone have it on condition that they pay it back later, often gradually, with an additional amount as interest
lend.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The government is trying to encourage the banks to lend more.
A lot of banks are unwilling to lend money to new businesses.
The building society agreed to lend us £60,000.
lend.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to give a situation, event etc a particular quality
lend.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The presence of members of the royal family lent a certain dignity to the ceremony.
lend.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to let someone borrow money or something that belongs to you for a short time
Did you lend that book to Mike?
The documents were loaned by the local library.
let somebody use something/let somebody have something
to let someone use something that belongs to you for a short time, especially a room, a house, or something big and expensive
Some friends are letting us use their house while they are on vacation.
Dad said he’d let me have his car for the weekend.
if something is on loan, it has been lent to a person or organization in an official way – often used about a library book or a work of art
The museum has an exhibition of paintings on loan from the Louvre.
According to the computer, this book is still out on loan.
lend.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: if a bank or financial institution lends money, it lets a person or organization borrow it on condition that they pay it back, with an additional amount as interest, usually gradually over an agreed period of time
lend.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Once again, the government is encouraging banks to lend.
Last year, financial institutions lent over $30 billion to new businesses.
lend.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to let someone borrow money from you or use something that you own, which they will give back to you later
lend.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Can you lend me $20 till Friday?
Neighbouring countries offered to lend rescue equipment to the city authorities after the earthquake.
lend.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to support or help someone or something
lend.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The bond market rally yesterday also lent some strength to the stock market.
The dollar’s weakness has lent support to precious metals prices.
